questions.text: A child was encouraged by his parents to follow a healthy lifestyle to prevent obesity. What level of prevention is adopted in this scenario?
questions.solution:
• Primordial prevention is adopted in this scenario.
  • The emergence of risk factors for obesity is prevented by encouraging the child to follow a healthy lifestyle from an early age. This reduces the probability of developing obesity in the future.

Reference Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page No 48, 49

questions.text: A Ph.D scholar wants to study the etiological factors leading to the development of Moebius syndrome. Which study design should she use?
questions.solution:
• Moebius syndrome is a rare disease so a case-control study should be used by the researcher to study the etiology of this disease.

Reference Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page No 70, 77, 79, 82, 87

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient came to the Suraksha clinic with the following presentation in the right inguinal region. Which of the following kits should be given to treat this patient?
questions.solution:
• The black kit should be used for the treatment of this patient
  • In the image shown above, the groove sign is seen in the inguinal region. It is the characteristic feature of lymphogranuloma venereum caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.
  • The black kit comprises tablet azithromycin 1 gm single dose + tablet doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 21 days.

Reference Online Resource: http://naco.gov.in/sites/default/files/Syndromic%20Poster_REDUCED.pdf

choices.text: Treatment for pneumonia would be covered, but treatment for paralysis would not be covered under this program.
Being a disabled citize n with no family, he would be automatically included in the scheme.
The maximum age limit to avail the benefits under this programme is 65 years, so he would not receive any benefits.
A registration fees of rupees 2000 is mandatory before enrolling into the program

questions.text: A 70-year-old disabled paraplegia patient from a rural area with no family was admitted to a tertiary health center for pneumonia. Which of the following is true regarding the benefits this patient would receive under the Ayushman Bharat - National Health Protection Mission?
questions.solution:
• In the given clinical scenario, the patient is a disabled citizen with no family so would be automatically included in the National Health Protection Mission which is a component of Ayushman Bharat.
  • Out of the total 7 deprivation criteria for rural areas, PM-JAY covers all such families who fall into at least one of the following 6 deprivation criteria and automatic inclusion criteria:
  • D1- Only one room with kucha walls and kucha roof
  • D2- No adult member between ages 16 to 59
  • D3- Households with no adult male member between ages 16 to 59
  • D4- Disabled member and no able-bodied adult member
  • D5- SC/ST households
  • D7- Landless households deriving a major part of their income from manual casual labour

Reference Online Resource https://pmjay.gov.in/sites/default/files/2018-09/PMJAY%20Brand%20Guidelines%2031st%20Aug%202018.pdf

https://pmjay.gov.in/sites/default/files/2018-09/PMJAY%20Brand%20Guidelines%2031st%20Aug%202018.pdf

questions.text: A couple married for 11 years lives with their 9-year-old son. What type of family is this called?
questions.solution:
The type of family described in the given scenario is a nuclear family.

Types of families:

  • A nuclear family or elementary family consists of only the married couple and their offspring while they are dependents.
  • The term new family is applied when nuclear families are younger than 10 years and consist of parents and children.
  • A joint family or extended family consists of a number of married couples and their children who live together in the same household with usually the men being related by blood. All property in joint families is held in common with the family income going into a common pocket. A senior male member is usually the head of the family who makes decisions.
  • A three-generation family is one where there are representatives from three different generations in one house.
  • A communal family is one in which all the members play a part in its management.

Reference Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page No 739, 740

questions.text: A woman delivers a baby through the caesarean section and returns home after 5 days. An ASHA worker would make how many visits post-delivery to evaluate the condition of the newborn and the mother?
questions.solution:
• In the given scenario, an ASHA worker would make 5 visits post-delivery to evaluate the condition of the newborn and the mother.
  • The woman delivers a baby through the caesarean section and returns home after 5 days. The ASHA worker should ideally make the first visit on day 7 and thereafter 4 visits till day 42.

The home visits of ASHA workers post-delivery are:

  • 7 visits after home delivery on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28, and 42
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28, and 42
  • 5 visits after caesarean section delivery, first visit on day 7, and thereafter 4 visits till day 42.

Reference Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page No 496

questions.text: The Sp02 values of 5 patients in a COVID-19 ward are given below. Which of the following statements is true? 90%, 92%, 92%, 92%, 94%
questions.solution:
• In the given scenario, mean = median = mode.
  • The mean is the sum of all the elements divided by the number of elements in the distribution. In this scenario, the mean = (90 + 92 + 92 + 92 + 94) / 5 = 460/5= 92%
  • The median divides the frequency distribution in half when all the scores are listed in order. When a distribution has an odd number of elements, the median is the middle value. When the distribution has an even number of elements, the median is the average of the two middle scores. In this scenario, the median = 92% which is the middle value.
  • The mode is the observed value that occurs with the greatest frequency. In this scenario, the mode = 92% Hence, the mean = median = mode = 92%
  • Other options:

Options B and C - Mean = Mode = Median = 92%. Hence options B and C are incorrect.

Option D - There is only one value that occurs with the greatest frequency. Hence, the frequency distribution is unimodal. If two values occur with the greatest frequency then the frequency distribution is bimodal. If more than two values occur with the greatest frequency then the distribution is multimodal.

Reference High-Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health - 4th Edition Page No 8, 9

questions.text: An 18-year-old unmarried girl comes to you for advice on contraception. Which of the following contraception methods would you suggest to her?
questions.solution:
• In the given scenario, a condom should be suggested as a method of contraception in an adolescent unmarried girl.
  • Condoms prevent unwanted pregnancies and sexually transmitted infections. It is a barrier method of contraception and is preferable in adolescents. Young, unmarried girls are at risk for getting pregnant who then resort to legal or illegal abortions performed under unsatisfactory conditions. This can increase mortality or cause complications like secondary sterility.

Other options:

  • Options A and C - Diaphragm and cervical cap are not suitable in adolescents because they are complicated to use and young people lack the skills to use them. These contraception methods also require foreseeing of sexual intercourse which is not possible in young adolescents due to their behavior of having occasional sex with different partners.

Option D - Intra-uterine contraceptive device (UCD) are contraindicated because of the risk of developing pelvic infection and secondary sterility,

Notes: Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are preferred for adolescent girls because they generally do not suffer from any cardiovascular diseases. They are also completely reversible and do not modify the future fertility of these girls. However, OCPs do not protect against HIV/AIDs.

Reference Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page No 562, 563

questions.text: What is the glucose content of ReSoMal?
questions.solution:
• The glucose content of ReSoMal is 125 mmol/L.
  • ReSoMal stands for Rehydration Solution for Malnutrition

Reference Online Resource https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5657219/

Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page No 244,247

questions.text: The measures that are taken to prevent a disaster from causing emergencies or to lessen the likely effects of emergencies are a part of
questions.solution:
• The measures that are taken to prevent disasters from causing emergencies or to lessen the likely effects of emergencies are part of disaster mitigation.
  • Disaster mitigation also includes measures taken to lessen the likely effects of emergencies.

Reference Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page No 857-860

questions.text:
Which of the following are the chief aims of the following organization?
1. Better condition of rural people
2. Improve nutrition
3. Increase efficiency of farming, forestry, and fisheries
4. Promote global climate protection
5. Eliminate hunger
questions.solution:
• Statements 1, 2, and 3 are correct about the organization shown in the image
  • This image is the logo of the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO).
  • Its primary aim is to Help nations raise living standards and-
  • Improve the nutrition of people of all countries
  • Increase the efficiency of farming, forestry, and fisheries
  • Improve the condition of rural people
  • The FAO organized a Freedom from Hunger Campaign (FFHC) in 1960 with the objective to combat malnutrition and to disseminate information and education.

Reference Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th Page No 986

questions.text: Match the following thermometers with their applications:
questions.solution:
• The correct match is 1-d, 2-a, 3-b, 4-C.
  • A dry bulb thermometer is an ordinary thermometer used to measure the air temperature.
  • A globe thermometer is used for the direct measurement of the mean radiant temperature of the surroundings.
  • A wet globe thermometer is used for measuring environmental heat. It exchanges heat with the surroundings by conduction, convection, evaporation, and radiation so the equilibrium temperature of the globe provides a comprehensive measure of the cooling capacity of the work environment.
  • A kata thermometer was originally used to measure the cooling power of the air (air temperature, humidity, and air movement) but currently, it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities.
  • A wet kata reading of 20 and above and a dry kata reading of 6 and above were taken as indices of thermal comfort.

Reference Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page No 806, 807

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding the Ebola virus?
1. It occurs periodically
2. It is infectious during the incubation period
3. It is not infectious in asymptomatic patients
4. There is no vaccine against the Ebola virus
5. It is transmitted through the air
questions.solution:
• Statements 1 and 3 are true about the Ebola virus.
  • Following are true for the Ebola virus-
  1. It is caused by Filoviridae family and occurs periodically.
  2. It is not infectious during the incubation period of 2-21 days.
  3. It is not infectious in asymptomatic patients.
  4. There is a vaccine available against the Ebola virus. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approved the Ebola vaccine rVSV-ZEBOV (called Ervebo) on the 19th of December 2019, which is the first FDA-approved vaccine for Ebola. This vaccine is given as a single dose vaccine and is safe and protective against Zaire ebolavirus.
  5. The virus is transmitted through direct contact with infected animals blood/organs/body secretions/body fluids. Human to human transmission is through blood/body fluids/objects that are contaminated with secretions of an infected symptomatic person. It is not transmitted through air, water, or food.
  6. Its clinical features are sudden onset of fever, intense weakness, muscle pain, headache, sore throat, vomiting, diarrhoea, rash, impaired kidney and liver functions, and internal and external bleeding.
  7. At present, it has no specific treatment. Although, intensive support and care can reduce mortality.
  8. Its spread can be prevented by instituting specific infection control measures.

Reference Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page No 384

Online Resource https://www.cdc.gov/vhf/ebola/prevention/index.html

choices.text: From onset of rash to 3 days after rash onset
2 weeks before rash to 1 week after rash onset
During full course of the disease
From catarrhal stage to 7 days after rash onset

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents with complaints of fever and rash. The fever was first seen 5 days back and the rash started 2 days back on the face and has progressed to his trunk. He is diagnosed with measles. What is the recommended period of isolation for measles?
questions.solution:
• The isolation period for measles is from the catarrhal stage to 7 days after the onset of the rash.
  • The incubation period is commonly 10 days from exposure to onset of fever, and 14 days from appearance of the rash.
  • The period of communicability is approximately 4 days before and 4 days after the appearance of the rash.
  • Isolation of the patient for a week from the onset of rash more than covers the period of communicability.

References Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page No:160, 161

questions.text: According to the Sample registration system (SRS) 2021 statistical data, the crude birth rate and crude death rate in India (per 1000 mid-year population) are
questions.solution:
• According to the SRS 2021 update, the crude birth rate and death rate in India are 19.7 and 6 respectively.
  • The birth rate is the number of live births per thousand population in a given region and year. It is a crude measure of the fertility of a population. It is a crucial determinant of population growth. The birth rate of India has considerably declined over the past 4 decades.
  • The death rate is the number of deaths per thousand population in a given region and time period. It is a simple measure of the mortality of a population. The death rate of India has considerably declined over the past 4 decades.

Note: This SRS report published in 2021 corresponds to the reference year 2019.

Reference Online Resource https://censusindia.gov.in/vital_statistics/SRS_Bulletins/SRS%20Bulletin%202019.pdf

questions.text: What is the range of body mass index (BMI) for class I obesity in the global population?
questions.solution:
• The range of BMI for class I obesity for the global population is 30.00-34.99.
  • People categorized as class I, class II, and class Ill obesity have moderate, severe, and very severe susceptibility to comorbidities respectively.
  • Body mass index (BMI) is a statistical index of weight-for-height that is commonly used to classify underweight, overweight, and obesity in adults. It is defined as the weight in kilograms divided by the square of the height in meters (kg/m2).

Reference Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page No. 428

questions.text:
You are the medical officer of a health center in an urban city. The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare urges the active screening of high-risk groups for tuberculosis according to the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program. You are tasked with sending health workers to conduct active case-finding activity. Arrange the following groups in the order of priority to be screened, from highest to the lowest.
1. NACO identified high-risk groups for HIV
2. Old age homes
3. Prisons inmates
4. Refugee camps
questions.solution:
• The order of priority of active case finding activity (ACF) in an urban area is in the order of 3 > 2 > 4 > 1 according to the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP) 2017 - 2025
  • Under the NTEP, the requirements for moving towards TB elimination have been integrated into the four strategic pillars of 'Detect - Treat - Prevent - Build' (DTPB).

Under 'Detect', the NTEP aims to:

  1. Scale-up free, high sensitivity diagnostic tests and algorithms
  2. Scale-up effective private provider engagement approaches
  3. Universal testing for drug-resistant TB
  4. Systematic screening of high-risk populations

Active case finding activity (ACF) in vulnerable groups is a focus over the next 5 years and considerable efforts are made to reach these populations.

Reference Online Resource https://tbcindia.gov.in/WriteReadData/NSP%20Draft%2020.02.2017%201.pdf

questions.text: Identify the type of statistical plot shown below.
questions.solution:
• The image shown is of a symmetric funnel plot.
  • A funnel plot is basically a scatter plot of individual studies which are used in systematic reviews and meta-analysis. It plots their precisions and results.
  • In a funnel plot, each dot represents an individual study.
  • The y-axis is usually the standard error or another estimate of precision and the x-axis is the outcome, usually the odds ratio.
  • Higher powered studies are placed towards the top and the lower powered ones towards the bottom such that the plot resembles an inverted funnel or a pyramid.
  • This shape is expected as different studies have different standard errors and other estimates.

Reference High-Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health - 4th Edition Pg 61, 62

questions.text: Which committee recommended the introduction of a multipurpose health worker scheme in India?
questions.solution:
• The Kartar Singh Committee introduced the multipurpose health worker scheme in India.
  • It was established in 1972 and it submitted its report in 1973.
  • It is also called the Committee on Multipurpose Workers under Health and Family Planning. This committee recommended the following:
  • Male and female health workers; 1 PHC for 50,000 population
  • Each PHC to have 16 sub-centres
  • Each sub-center to have one male and one female health worker

Reference Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page no: 938

questions.text: With the introduction of a labor room in your primary healthcare center, you being the chief medical officer, are expected to practice steps of the Baby-friendly Hospital Initiative (BFHI). This global initiative aims to
questions.solution:

questions.text: All of the following are true about pyrethrum except: (DDT: Dichloro-diphenyl-trichloroethane)
questions.solution:
• The residual action of pyrethrum is not as good as that of DDT.
  • The drawback of using pyrethrum is that it lacks the residual action of DDT and other insecticides.

Reference Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page no: 844, 845

questions.text: Which of the following is the most logical sequence?
questions.solution:
• Disease → Impairment → Disability → Handicap is the most logical sequence among the given options.
  • Disease is a state of physiological/psychological dysfunction.
  • Impairment is any loss or abnormality in normal structure or function.
  • Disability is the inability to carry out normal actions due to impairment.
  • Handicap is the disadvantage due to disability that limits fulfilment of a role that is normal.

Reference Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page 39, 50

questions.text: Kuppuswamy scale considers all except
questions.solution:
• The Kuppuswamy scale doesn't include housing.
  • The Kuppuswamy scale was designed to classify the socio-economic status in urban and peri-urban areas.
  • It was devised in 1976 by Kuppuswamy and was later modified to be called the Modified Kuppuswamy scale.

This scale uses the following components:

1.Education of head of the family

2.Occupation of the head of the family

3.Monthly income of the family

Reference Journal http://msjonline.org/index.php/ijrms/article/viewFile/3310/3113

questions.text: A pregnant woman has come for her first antenatal visit at 10 weeks of gestation. How many more antenatal visits does she require to fulfill the minimum requirements as per the Maternal and Child Health program?
questions.solution:
• This patient requires 3 more antenatal visits in order to fulfill the minimum requirements according to Maternal and Child Health Program (MCH).
  • The minimum number of antenatal visits according to MCH is 4.
  • 1st visit - within 12 weeks, preferably as soon as the pregnancy is suspected.
  • 2nd visit - between 14 and 26 weeks
  • 3rd visit - between 28 and 34 weeks
  • 4th visit - between 36 weeks and term
  • The minimum number of antenatal visits according to the WHO is 8. Ideally, pregnant women should attend antenatal visits according to the following schedule:

Once a month during the first 7 months

  • Twice a month during the 8th month
  • Once a week, thereafter if everything is normal.

Reference Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page no 575

questions.text: Which among the following is not a risk factor for severe illness in a patient with COVID-19?
questions.solution:
• Young age is not a risk factor for severe illness in a patient with COVID-19.

questions.solution:
• The given image is the logo of the World Health Organization, WHO that has its headquarters located in Geneva, Switzerland.
  • WHO is a specialized, non-political health agency of the United Nations.
  • It came into force on the 7'' of April 1948. Its prime objective is the attainment by all people of the highest level of health.
  • The structure of the WHO comprises the World Health Assembly, the Executive Board, and the Secretariat.

questions.text:
A researcher is preparing to do a cohort study on the gastroenterology wards to determine the association of H. pylori with inflammatory bowel disease. Which of the following are true regarding the advantages of this study?
1. Attrition is low
2. Incidence can be calculated
3. Provides a direct estimate of relative risk
4. Short period of time for completion of the study
5. Bias like misclassification can be minimized
questions.solution:
• Among the given statements, the true statements regarding the advantages of cohort studies are 2, 3, and 5
  • The advantages of cohort study are the following:

-The incidence can be calculated.

-Several possible outcomes related to -exposure can be studied simultaneously

-Provides a direct estimate of relative risk

-Dose-response ratios can be calculated

-Bias like misclassification can be minimized

Reference Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page no: 87. 91

questions.text: A patient with sepsis was transferred to another hospital. Airing and sunning of his room, furniture, and bedding was then done by the hospital staff. Which among the following methods of cleaning/disinfection was used in this scenario?
questions.solution:
• In the given scenario, terminal cleaning is used as a cleaning method.
  • Terminal cleaning is the process of airing and sunning the rooms, furniture, and bedding of a patient who has died or has been shifted to another hospital or after cessation of isolation.
  • The room is cleaned with a detergent by the hospital staff so that a new patient can be admitted to that room.
  • Currently, this method is used in place of terminal disinfection and is considered adequate.

Types of disinfection are:

  • Terminal disinfection is the application of disinfective measures after the patient has died or has been shifted to another hospital or after cessation of isolation. It is rarely done now and has been replaced by terminal cleaning.
  • Concurrent disinfection is the application of disinfection methods after discharge of infectious material from the body of an infected person or soiling.
  • Precurrent/prophylactic disinfection is the application of preventive measures like pasteurization of milk, chlorination of water, and handwashing.

Reference Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page No 139, 140

questions.text: All the passengers coming to India were screened for COVID-19 at the airport. Which type of screening is done in this scenario?
questions.solution:
• The type of screening done for the immigrants to a country is prospective screening.
  • Prospective screening is done for disease control. People are examined for the benefit of others.
  • It may lead to an early diagnosis and permit more effective treatment.
  • It also reduces the spread of infectious diseases in the community.
  • Hence, reduces mortality associated with the disease. Examples of prospective screening are:
  • Screening of immigrants from infectious diseases such as tuberculosis and syphilis to protect the home population
  • Screening for streptococcal infection to prevent rheumatic fever

Reference Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page No 149, 150

questions.text:
Which of the following bio-medical waste materials are disposed of in yellow bags?
1. Expired drugs
2. Latex gloves
3. Placenta
4. Blood bag
5. Used pacemaker
questions.solution:

Other options:

questions.solution:

questions.text: A 53-year-old painter comes to the OPD with constipation and foot drop. On investigation, peripheral blood smear shows the following finding. Toxicity of which of the following agents is this patient suffering from?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario shows a painter with constipation, foot drop and basophilic stippling.
  • He is most likely suffering from lead toxicity.
  • Lead exerts its toxic action by combining with the SH-group of enzymes involved in porphyrin synthesis and carbohydrate metabolism.
  • It disrupts normal membrane permeability and causes potassium leakage in RBCs.

Reference Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page no 868-870

  • The Arabs invented the art of prescription writing.

questions.text: According to the Factories Act, 1948, a safety officer should be employed if the number of workers is more than
questions.solution:
• According to the Factories Act, 1948, a safety officer should be employed if the number of workers is more than 1000.
  • The Factories Act, 1948 states the following regarding safety and welfare measures:
    • > 1000 workers - there should be a safety officer
    • > 500 workers - there should be a welfare officer
    • > 250 workers - a canteen should be provided
    • > 30 female workers- a crèche should be provided

Reference Park Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine - 24th Edition Page no 852

questions.text: A target group is being tested by three screening tests for breast cancer as a part of a research program. The patient is considered diseased if she tests positive in all of the screening tests. Which of the following is false about this combination of screening tests?
questions.solution:
• The given scenario shows a number of screening tests being conducted in series, where the net sensitivity is low.
  • Since the patient is considered diseased only if she is positive in all three tests, this combination of screening tests is said to be in series.
  • The combination of two or more tests performed together can help to enhance the efficacy of detecting the presence or absence of disease.

References

Medical Biostatistics Page no 190, 191

Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page no 153

questions.text: The tribal and hilly areas should have one health sub-center for how much population?
questions.solution:
• According to the present norms, tribal and hilly areas should have one health sub-center per 3000 population, one primary health center per 20,000 population, and one community health center per 80,000 population.

Reference

Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page no 763

questions.text: Hemoglobin levels were measured in 200 pregnant women. The results showed a mean hemoglobin level of 10.5 gm/dL with a standard deviation of 0.5 gm/dL. Assuming that the distribution is normal, how many women will have hemoglobin levels below 9.5 gm/dL?
questions.solution:
• 5 women will have hemoglobin (Hb) levels < 9.5 gm/dL.
  • Solution:
  • Mean Hb = 10.5 gm/dL
  • Standard deviation = 0.5 gm/dL

10.5 gm/dL - 9.5 gm/dL = 1 gm/dL. Since 0.5gm/dL is 1 S.D, 1gm/dL is 2 S.D. Therefore, 9.5 gm/dL is 2 S.D below mean Hb.

In other words, Mean-2 S.D= 10.5 - (2x 0.5) = 10.5 - 1 = 9.5.

  • Similarly, 11.5 gm/dL is 2 S.D above mean Hb.

In a normal distribution, 2 S.D from the mean will have 95% of the participants. Therefore 95% of pregnant women will have Hb levels between 9.5 to 11.5 gm/dl.

Remaining 2.5% women will have Hb >11.5 gm/dl and 2.5% women will have Hb level <9.5 gm/dI.

2.5% of 200 = 5 women will have Hb <9.5 gm/dI.

Reference

High-Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health - 4th Edition Page nos 11 and 12

questions.text: The COVID-19 outbreak is a type of ____________
questions.solution:
• This outbreak of COVID-19 is an example of a propagated epidemic.
  • The propagated epidemic results from a person to person transmission of the infectious agent over a prolonged duration of time.
  • In this scenario, the cases of COVID occurred over a period which is more than one incubation period of the disease.Other examples of a propagated epidemic include Hepatitis A and Polio.

Reference Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page no 72

choices.text: Inner square white, outer circle blue
Inner square blue, outer circle white
Outer square white, inner circle blue
Outer square blue, inner circle white

questions.text: In a primary health center, a nurse asks you about using a polio vaccine vial which has not crossed its expiry date. You look at the vaccine vial monitor (VVM) and tell her that it can be used. What did the VVM most likely show?
questions.solution:
• The standard polio vaccine vial monitor has an inner square and outer circle.
  • It can be used if the inner square is lighter than the outer circle.

Reference Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page no 121

questions.text: A study is performed where the mothers of both low birth weight (LBW) and normal birth weight babies are questioned regarding their intake of oral hypoglycemic agents (OHA) during the 1st trimester to determine the association of LBW and OH intake in the first trimester. Which measure of association is appropriate for this study?
questions.solution:
• The study design mentioned is a case-control study design to evaluate the strength of association between a risk factor and outcome.
  • Hence, the best-suited measure would be the odds ratio.

References

High-Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology, and Public Health (High-yield Series) Page no 94

Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page no. 86

questions.text: A child with bilateral cataracts, hearing loss, and known congenital heart defect was brought to the community health center with the following lesions that are present since birth. These are referred to as-
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario is suggestive of congenital rubella syndrome and the image shows blueberry muffin lesions which are characteristically associated with this syndrome.

Reference Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page no 164

questions.text: You are a medical officer actively spearheading the sexually transmitted diseases control program in your block. As part of this, the sexual partners of the diagnosed patients are identified, located, investigated, and treated for the disease. This type of case detection that is employed by your team is called
questions.solution:
• Method of case detection in control of STDs when the sexual partners of the diagnosed patients are identified, located, tested and treated is contact tracing.

Reference Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page No:367

choices.text: Local treatment with clotrimazole vaginal pessary
Give oral secnidazole to the patient
Treat the patient and her husband with acyclovir

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman at 14 weeks of gestation presents with vaginal discharge. She has no other complaints. On examination, greenish frothy discharge is present. No laboratory facilities are available. How would you proceed with management?
questions.solution:
• The patient should be administered a single dose of secnidazole 2g orally as she has trichomonas vaginitis in her second trimester of pregnancy.
  • This patient in her second trimester of pregnancy has greenish, frothy vaginal discharge that is suggestive of trichomoniasis. However, since laboratory tests are not available, they cannot be confirmed. Using the syndromic management of sexually transmitted infections, she should be treated with oral secnidazole.

Reference Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page no 362

questions.text: A population survey recently reported a surge in xerophthalmia cases among children between 6 months to 6 years of age. The following options show the prevalence of certain indicators of vitamin A deficiency in the population at risk. Which of them signifies that vitamin A deficiency is a public health problem?
questions.solution:
• Vitamin A deficiency is considered a public health problem if the prevalence rate of Bitot's spots is 5%, among several other criteria, in children between 6 months to 6 years of age.

Reference Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page no. 673

choices.text: Indicates trends in the entire target population
Identifying cases that are free of disability

questions.text: Which of the following is not part of sentinel surveillance?
questions.solution:
• Sentinel surveillance helps in identifying the missing cases among the old and new cases.
  • Sentinel surveillance is a method to identify the missing cases and hence supplement the notified cases.

References

Park Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine - 24th Edition Page no. 45, 69
